message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about the Earth's seasons and hemispheres. December is in the summer in the southern part of the third rock, which refers to the southern hemisphere of Earth. Option (A) is incorrect because the southern part of cities does not determine the seasons. Option (B) is incorrect because December is in the winter in the northern hemisphere. Option (D) is incorrect because not every rock, such as other planets or celestial bodies, follows the same seasonal patterns as Earth.

Option (A) is incorrect because the season in the southern part of cities depends on the hemisphere they are located in. Option (B) is incorrect because December is in the winter in the northern part of Earth. Option (D) is incorrect because the season in the southern part of every rock is not specified and could vary.

This question requires basic knowledge about the Earth's seasons and the tilt of its axis. In the northern hemisphere, December is in the winter because it is tilted away from the Sun. However, in the southern hemisphere, December is in the summer because it is tilted towards the Sun. Therefore, option (C) is correct because it states that December is in the summer in the southern part of the Earth, referred to as the "third rock." Option (A) is incorrect because it only considers the southern part of cities, which is not applicable to the entire Earth. Option (B) is incorrect because it only considers the northern part of Earth, which is not relevant to the question. Option (D) is incorrect because it states that December is in the southern part of every rock, which is not true as the seasons vary depending on the Earth's location and tilt.
